text: The human liver produces the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase, which detoxifies ethanol.
The biosynthesis of amino acids generates by-products that contribute both desirable flavors (long-chain alcohols) and offflavors (acetaldehyde and diacetyl).

Ethanol is unique among fermentation products in that it provides a significant source of caloric intake, but it is ethanol enters the human circulation naturally from intestinal flora, equivalent to a fraction of a drink per day.
Traditional forms of beer also provided essential vitamins in the unfiltered yeasts.
Ethanolic fermentation of grain or fruit was important to early civilizations because it provided a drink free of waterborne pathogens.
This enzyme in a healthy liver can metabolize small amounts of alcohol without harm.
Yeast fermentation generates ethanol in substantial quanti- ties.
■ Alcoholic fermentation in beer and wine.
